Answer 2: HiCAT will be held on November 26, 2017.Start Preparing From Now …How to prepare for CAT: What does it really take to crack CAT?CAT is the mother of all B-school entrance exams; not because it is the toughest, but because a huge number of aspirants take it and the maximum number of colleges only consider CAT scores, including the prestigious IIMs.Cracking CAT is dependent on a host of parameters- hard work, conceptual clarity, time management and above all, luck. But the most crucial traits that one must possess in order to prepare effectively for CAT are discipline, consistency and a never say die spirit. Cracking CAT is not about the three hours in the examination hall answering questions, but months of rigorous practice, sleepless nights and an indomitable spirit to fight it till the end.It is a test of one’s endurance, intellect and temperament. If you are able to maintain your composure throughout the journey, you will eventually be able to ace it. You need to have nerves of steel and an inextinguishable fire to excel at CAT.The CAT preparation strategy and study plan that aspirants must followThere’s no tailor made one size fits all study plan for CAT. It has to be customised according to one’s strengths, weaknesses and limitations, which will vary with every aspirant. But what I strongly advise candidates, is to be consistent. You must spare two-three hours every day for CAT preparation. I believe that at least 8-10 months of extensive preparation are required for a candidate to score a phenomenal percentile. Target to finish off the entire syllabus by August end or September first week.Then focus on the most important aspect, taking mocks and thoroughly analysing them. LRDI and Reading Comprehension need to be practised every day as these are sections that can be mastered only with regular practice and persistence.How is Kitabee different in its approach, when coaching aspirants for CAT?Kitabee is an institution that offers personal attention to every student catering to their individual needs and helping them chalk out as well as follow a customised study plan. Each student needs varied guidance and we ensure that they are given special consideration. We are able to achieve this as the batch strength varies from 10-12 students and helps us give each student the focused attention they deserve.Once the syllabus is over, the students go through rigorous training for the next three months with frequent revision sessions, workshops and mock tests to give them the thrust they need to perform exceptionally well on the D-day. Also, at Kitabee, every entrance exam is given equal importance and we train our students accordingly to excel in each such exam.The phenomenal results of our last batch speak great volumes about the quality of training that we impart to our students. Also keeping an affordable fee structure allows everyone to join Kitabee and get access to the exceptional coaching and learning.But in the end it all depends on the efforts you put in.All the best!KITABEE - 011-49124686
Answer 3: IIM CAT has now confirmed the CAT 2018 dates. Candidates who are waiting for the exam dates can check the complete information at IIMs To Hold CAT 2018 On 25 November 2018 [Exam Date Confirmed] .Previous year the exam conducted on last Sunday of November 2017. So this year also, following the similar pattern the exam will take place on Sunday, November 25 ,2018.For any queries, please ask in comment.Happy to share!
Answer 4: CAT 2018 will be held on Nov 25,2018.Here we have given some tips and tricks which you should follow while preparing for CAT.Tip #1. Take mock tests in an online environmentThis is really important and one should ignore it, Take the computer-based mock test so that you are familiarised with the actual test environment. Also, by taking the computer-based mock test, it helps you to prepare and save any wastage and you will be able to learn many tricks of how to solve the questions, which type of questions to opt first.Tip #2. Analyse Mock TestThe next thing to do is to analyze the mock test. It is more important than taking the mock test itself. After every CAT mock test, you must analyze your performance and evaluate your scoring areas.Shiv Raj secured 99.94 percentile in CAT and is an IIM Calcutta student, shares the preparation tipWHENEVER YOU TAKE A MOCK TEST, ASSESS NOT ONLY THE WRONG QUESTIONS BUT ALSO THE RIGHT ONES. SOMETIMES YOU MAY SCORE VERY HIGH, WHILE ON OTHER OCCASIONS YOU MIGHT GET A LOW SCORETip #3. Identify your strength and weaknessYou can not improve unless you don’t know what you are doing wrong or what is your strength or weaknesses. After every mock test, evaluate your performance, identify your weak areas, focus on it and start working on that.Tip #4. Practice Every DayThe experts suggest that you must practice a lot so that you can make an instant connect with the question during your CAT exam day. Practicing regularly will not only help you increase your question-solving speed but will also make you habitual to sit for three hours.Chhavi Gupta, CAT 2017 100 Percentile shares,“I RIGOROUSLY PRACTISED THE MOCK CAT SERIES, SELECTED SOME RANDOM TESTS ONLINE AND SAMPLE CAT. TO BE PRECISE, I SOLVED 35 PRACTICE TESTS AND ANALYSING THEM CRITICALLY”So preparation accordingly and ALL THE BEST !!!

Question: What should be my strategy if I am aiming CAT 2018?
Tags on question: Common Admission Test (CAT) 2018, CAT Preparation, Common Admission Test (CAT), Exam and Test Preparation, Jobs and Careers, Career Advice
Answer 1: Planning ahead in advance is the right move thus, you are currently on right track. CAT is one of the most difficult and challenging exam. It requires a well planned comprehensive study plan. You need not to study 5–6 hours daily and be stressed all the time. You need to act smart and prepare wisely.If you currently at level zero and know nothing about CAT begin your preparation with getting yourself acquainted with structure and syllabus of the exam. CAT has 3 sections i.e. Reading comprehension and Verbal Ability, Quantitative Aptitude, Data Interpretation and Logical Reasoning. Find out all the key elemental topics that forms the course structure of these sections.Develop the basics: Initially begin with familiarizing and understanding the curriculum and concepts of each of the above given sections.Solve past papers: solving past CAT papers is must and essential this will give you an idea what level you should match to crack CAT.Mocks & their analysis: Mocks are really very important it's analysis tells your weaker areas and strength so that you can improve and manage your time accordingly.You have two choices in terms of the platform to prepare for CAT.(i) Online Coaching(ii) Classroom ProgramsI personally recommend you to join a online study program. It’s more flexible and affordable than classroom program and by no means lesser than the offline coaching centers in terms of support and education they provide. One such online study program is HANDA ka Funda. It is a leading exhaustive and extensive online program for CAT aspirants. It provides 750+ pre-recorded videos that includes all the significant concepts each followed up with an example to help students to develop methodology and applicability of the all key basics and concepts that cover up all 3 sections.You will get access to the video tutorials which comprises of the concept videos, solved examples and previous year CAT questions. These videos are available 24x7 so that you can watch them anytime and as many times as you want.There is round a clock availability of Ravi Handa sir the chief instructor of the program to support and help students whenever they need that . He makes sure that the doubts of the students are solved and discussed and that's why he has open up discussion forums and conducts live sessions every week for personal assistance.There's also a free HANDA ka Funda app where you will find a great deal of important information about CAT that will help in your preparation.HANDA ka Funda is an excellent online platform for CAT aspirants that provides 10 pack mock series test. They have been made to test the progress of students and buildup accuracy in problem solving required for CAT preparation. You can know more about it here: Online Coaching for CAT and Banking ExamsNot everything can be taught somethings we have to develop on our own. A study program only provides the means to solve questions. It’s you who have to give the exam at the end of the day. Therefore, the most important role is played by you. You need to be serious and learn & practice diligently and consistently as you will be the one who will reap the fruits of your hard work. So work hard, take rest, be confident and keep practicing you will reach the topmost step of the ladder of success.All the best:)
Answer 2: ABOUT MEAt the time of writing this answer, I am a final year student at DTU. CAT 2017 was my first attempt, and I scored 99.98 percentile (scaled score - 222.81). My sectionals are: VARC - 98.15 (71.07), LRDI - 99.76 (53.68), QA - 100 (98.09). My past academic record is: Class 10th - 10 CGPA, Class 12th - 95%, Grad - 77% (up to 7th semester).In the days after the CAT 2017 result got announced, I got hundreds of queries from friends, seniors, juniors and random people from across the wide internet. So I decided to post an answer on a public platform, so that it may be used by anyone wishing to excel at CAT.DISCLAIMERThis was my first attempt at CAT. I do not claim to be an expert. This answer simply lists my own views and things which helped me succeed at CAT. Different things might apply to different people.BACKGROUNDI began my preparation in August 2016, at the beginning of my 3rd year. I was a classroom student at TIME Delhi. Simultaneously I joined the Facebook group iQuanta (Log into Facebook | Facebook), which was a group for like-minded CAT aspirants. I think iQuanta played the biggest role in my preparation. Even when I couldn't go to classes due to exams or other reasons, I kept solving questions on the group.Moreover, I was pretty good at Maths and English ever since my school days, owing in most part to JEE and board exam prep. This also made it easier for me to face DI sets. So basically my weakest section when I started out was LRDI, and especially LR.Initially, I spent most of my time strengthening the QA section, often neglecting the other sections. This became a problem for me once the mock season started because even though I was doing well in QA and VARC, my LRDI scores were lagging far behind. Another reason was that I had no defined strategy for LRDI, and hence I often went haywire if I had to face a difficult set. So August 2017 onward, I spent most of my time on LRDI, solving questions and developing my own strategies.I did not spend much time studying from books. I've always believed that practice is the best form of preparation. So I invested most of my time in doing practice questions and giving mocks, and as I said solving questions on iQuanta. Giving mocks is probably the most important thing one has to do in their CAT preparation. It prepares you for all sorts of possibilities.IMPORTANCE OF COACHINGI took coaching. I was part of the classroom course at one of the most renowned institutes. And personally, I’ve come to feel that classroom coaching is not necessary for CAT. There are amazing web courses available like iQuanta, at a fraction of the price of the classroom courses. The best strategy for an aspirant would be to take 2 mock series from renowned institutes, 1 booklet series, and then make use of any one web course. I’ve myself found iQuanta (CAT Preparation - IQuanta) to be the best in their domain.SECTION WISE STRATEGYSo keeping that background in mind, here are some tips and tricks, advice and suggestions, that helped me get a high score. Keep in mind that no trick is a substitute for hard work. Each and every aspirant would have one or two strong sections, and the other not-so-strong or weak sections. If it is your strongest area, make it your fort. No matter how difficult the questions, they shouldn't be able to budge you.VARC - This looks like it is the easiest section, and often it is. After all, we've all learned English all through our education. But it isn't. And for most people, it is really difficult to differentiate between an easy, and a tricky section.To improve at VARC, the first step is to improve your reading speed. Because you cannot do well in this section unless you can go through all 34 questions. So read a lot. Any source whatsoever. Prefer to use diverse sources to improve your domain knowledge of various fields at the same time. Quora is a wonderful resource, use it.Most of the practice that one needs for this section can be gained from mocks, and you can improve immensely if you work hard.LRDI - This is the weakest section for most, if not all aspirants. And frankly speaking, there is no book or mock series available that can prepare you for CAT level LRDI. But what can prepare you is having a good strategy.My strategy was that even before starting with the first set, I read all of the 8 sets, and set a priority order in which I was going to attempt them. This usually takes about 5-6 mins, but that time is worth spending. In a CAT-like situation, with a tough LRDI section, while others got stuck in tougher sets, I raced ahead and did not have to worry at any moment.Also, read and try to understand wide-ranging business scenarios. Over the last couple of years CAT has moved on to very practical scenarios in its questions (restaurants, ticket reservation etc.), and if you can understand the underlying logic, it becomes easier to solve the set.QA - Probably the one section where you have the highest likelihood of increasing your score. The score in this section often differentiates a 99.5 percentiler and a 100 percentiler (about 30 marks differentiate them).The QA section is where the Facebook group iQuanta helped me immensely. Any aspirant who isn’t a member of this group, must join immediately. I started solving doubts from other people in this group, and I really enjoyed doing it. And because of that, I was introduced to a huge variety of questions that I might never have faced otherwise.The strategy for a good QA section is to have sound basics. So if anyone is struggling with basics, start with NCERT textbooks. Because if you have good basics, you'll be able to visualize each and every problem, and would often be able t predict what the question setter is going to ask, even before reading the entire question.CONCLUSIONAt last, just remember that CAT isn't a difficult exam. It is just testing some core skills and nothing advanced. Just push yourself with the mantra, "If I can't, then no one can".
Answer 3: When you’re talking about the CAT (regardless of whether its CAT 2017 or 2018 or 2019) and the strategy one needs to crack the exam, there are two major questions which you need to ask yourself.1. How comfortable are you with the three (QA/DI-LR/VA) sections which are a part of the exam?This is an important question, perhaps more important than any question you might answer in the actual exam. That’s cause the spectre of sectional cutoffs means that you have to be ‘good’ in all three sections, or at the very least ‘good’ in two and passable in one. A weakness in one section will prove fatal for your entire examination.2. What is your background? and how expressive are you as a person?The story of the GEM with 99+ percentile who could not convert a good b school is so oft repeated now that its become a bit of a cliche at this point .Educational background is immensely important here. Additionally, a good CAT percentile is not the be all-end all of the B school journey. Getting selected in the high pressure environment of a GD/PI is a different ball game altogether. You’ve probably heard of enough people with good percentiles who choked when it came to expressing themselves on the ‘big stage’ so I won’t try to scare you with their stories at this point.In my opinion, what you need is a comprehensive guideline on how to crack the exam. Not only do you need an entity which can help you get a good percentile in this exam, you’ll also need someone to help you become more expressive and capable of handling pressure during the Interview/GD process.This ‘entity’ I’ve spoken about could be anyone. It could be a teacher, a mentor, a friend, a coaching institute …anyone who can help you perform the dual tasks of cracking the exam+cracking the GD/PI process.For this purpose, I would suggest Breakspace (Breakspace | Home). A picture is worth a thousand words, and this effectively conveys all I have to say about this institute.The rest I leave to your intelligence and discretion.
Answer 4: THANKS for A2ACommon admission test can be cleared by having good aptitude, English. If you dont have, you can learn, practice and get a good CAT Score.The first thing you need to do is have a unshakable belief that you can ace the CAT because you will see lots of ups and downs in these few months so it’s really important to not to loose focus.Do not stress yourself too much with the preparation. Do not imprison yourself with the preparation plan alone. Spend time doing your favorite activities too.Hard Work is the key to success!Stick with this strategy throughout your preparations and success will follow you. Believe in your strategy and more importantly in yourself.Next you need is a strategy or a game plan for next few months. No one can tell you whats the best way to prepare for for you but there are some basic guidelines which will help you find your way.You have so much time before you take the shot .One thing i will suggest you is read,read and read!! Read Hindu editorials,international newspaper and make your opnion on the national ,international issues and more importantly work more on your overall profile including extracurricular and acads (as you are still in college)Before you start full fledged preparation , I will suggest you to take an diagnostic testfor CAT(or past year paper) to know where you stand in terms of level of your Maths,English ,LR/DI .Quantitative Aptitude and Data Interpretation: Practice is the key here. There are hardly any topics which take more than 2 hours to complete. But without practicing it is as good as nothing.Verbal Ability and Reading Comprehension: Read. Read. Read. Reading is the exercise for brain and just any other muscle you need workout to improve its capability. Take up reading as your favorite pastime. Try to read extensive opinionated / argumentative articles from good sources viz. British magazines, English newspapers, etc. Not only should you read it fast, but also understand how the writer flows the article and reaches a conclusion.Offline coaching brings in the benefit of being disciplined by the schedule. You are pulled up for missing classes and the home work, recommendations for the next week or fortnight keeps you going.In case you want to join any coaching Institute, I will suggest you to join KITABEE , It has maximum students clearing CAT exam in terms of Percentage. Very qualified faculty.For any aspirant, the following factors are of prime importance when it comes to joining a coaching institute:1. [math]Personal[/math] [math]attention[/math] - I think the most important factor is this. If personal attention and mentoring is missing, don't join. When you are evaluating institutes, go and check their classrooms for batch size. Ask for a demo session, if possible. Go and take a demo class you will realize why i am suggesting KITABEE.2.[math] Faculty[/math] - In addition to point 1, look for faculties who have gone through the whole process as they can understand you better and guide you better. Ask for faculty details. See if you can talk to them. According to me “[math]Neeraj[/math] [math]sir[/math]” is the best teacher just call him and ask any doubt if you have. [math]7838804491[/math], 9718375475, 9540897459.3. [math]Content/Material/mocks[/math] -At KITABEE content is getting frequently updated to match the recent trends. As I said, not a differentiating factor. Mocks used to be a differentiating factor, go and visit Kitabee Site.In KITABEE you will get ample of materials to practise. There will be regular classes and after the completion of the class you will be given handouts which will comprise of the same thing taught in class . You should manage your time so well that you should practise every material. The study material are designed in such a way that it matches with CAT level. Believe me if you just do the study material religiously you will surely score more than 90 percentile. Besides that you will be given sectional tests which will be little advanced . And then comes the NEERAJ SIR’S AIMCAT.Clearing your doubts is another important thing to follow every timeKitabee focuses even on other exams like IIFT, SNAP, NMAT, XAT etc and regular mocks and revision sessions help the students perform better in these exams as each and every exam is a different ball game and needs a different strategy to excel.As the number of students is less there is a personal bond between the students and the mentors and this makes the faculty members very much approachable. Neraj Sir and Pratik Sir are a constant source of motivation for the students and help them work harder and harder.This pic was uploaded by Kitabee on Facebook …KITABEE WILL HELP YOU IN ANALYZING ……….What are your areas of strength? For Example, Quant is your area of strength. Jolly Good!! Which subjects do you excel in Quant. Algebra, Trigonometry, Geometry ?? Make sure you score cent percent in them. What are your areas of weakness?? Probability. Make sure you learn the basics to exploit the low hanging fruits.What are your areas of weakness? For example, VA (verbal ability). Which parts do you score in VA. Synonyms/Antonyms, Paragraph reading, Sentence corrections. Awesome!! Concentrate only on these areas and make sure this is enough to cross the line.Enroll for a test package.Give each test as if it the d-day. Determine time allocations as per your comfort. I generally follow 30–30–30–10 rule. 30% of time per each section to cross the line and final 10% of time to maximize my score.Your preparation doesn't end here. It starts now. After each test, go through each answer diligently. This helps you evaluate your strengths and weakness.For example, you fumbled with Data sets. Great!! Go back to basics. Read and solve everything you can lay hand on for the next one week. Your aim for the next test should be zero mistakes in Data sets.On a normal basis, your All India percentile in these tests is more or less your upcoming CAT score unless you somehow achieve super powers on the D-day and perform exceedingly well.Believe in yourSELF AND IN KITABEE ……!Aren’t you convinced yet. Well, that’s how I made it during my CAT being an average student, from an average college.And its a separate ball game altogether, if you are talking about GDPI.All the best!! Work smart, bell the CAT!!RegardsRahul

Means you have to complete degree at the time of admission.There are some more eligibility criteria that must be fulfill:CAT aspirant must have a bachelor degree in any discipline with 50% marks or equivalent CGPA.SC, ST, PWD candidates have a relax of 5% in academic qualification means they must have 45% marks or equivalent CGPA.Candidate must have complete there bachelor degree from any university/collage recognized by UGC, AICTE, MHRD, UPSC, AIU New delhi.CAT aspirant must have minimum 20 year old and there is no upper limit of age for applying CAT exam.CAT is the toughest exam so CAT is allows any candidate for infinite time means you can apply as much time as you want.If you are looking any Online CAT course you can go through here: Online Coaching for CAT and Banking ExamsHope this helps you.Cheers!!!

Earlier All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) used to conduct this exam every year across the country as per the directions of Ministry of Human Resource Development (MHRD), Government of India. The registration cum application process for this computer-based CMAT 2019 exam will start on Thursday, November 01, 2019.CMAT 2019 Eligibility CriteriaNTA has laid down the following eligibility criteria of CMAT 2019:The applicants should be citizens of IndiaAspirants should have a Bachelor’s degree in any stream from a recognised college/institute or universityFinal year graduation students are also eligible, provided their final result is declared before the commencement of admission.
